options.text: After approach clearance has been issued, provided that level flight above the transition altitude is not indicated or anticipated.

variant.question: The primary area of an instrument approach segment is:

options.text: A defined area symmetrically disposed about the nominal flight track in which the Minimum Obstacle Clearance is provided.
The outside part of the segment where the obstacle clearance increases from zero ft to the appropriate minimum.
The most critical part of the segment where the minimum altitude should be kept to very carefully.
The first part of the segment.

The first part of the segment ;

What is V~REF~?

options.text: The speed of the aeroplane, in specified landing configuration, at the point where it descends through the landing screen height, used in the determination of the landing distance for manual landings
The speed of the aeroplane, in specified landing configuration, at the point where it descends through the inner marker, used in the determination of the landing distance for manual landings
The speed of the aeroplane, in specified takeoff configuration, at the point where it climbs through the takeoff screen height, used in the determination of the takeoff distance
The speed of the aeroplane, in clean configuration, at the point where it descends through the landing screen height, used in the determination of the landing distance for manual landings

variant.question: What is V~EF~  ?

options.text: V~EF~  means the speed at which the critical engine is assumed to fail during take-off
V~EF~  means the minimum speed in the take-off at which the pilot must take the first action  stop the aeroplane within the accelerate-stop distance
V~EF~  means the minimum speed at which take-off can be safely continued following emergency system failure
V~EF~   means the maximum speed in the take-off at which the pilot must take the first action  stop the aeroplane within the accelerate-stop distance

variant.question: What is V~AT~?

options.text: The lesser of VSO or VS1G

variant.question: What is the purpose of the final segment of an instrument approach?

options.text: This is the segment in which alignment and descent for landing are made.
This segment is used in emergencies only.
This segment permits transition from the en-route phase to the approach phase.
This segment permits speed reduction between the intermediate approach fix and the final approach fix.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the ITCZ is correct?

options.text: Its associated weather is characterized by strong convergence and frequently heavy cumuliform clouds.
It is typically created by converging NW and SE trade winds.
In the Southern hemisphere summer (January) it is normally positioned entirely south of the Equator.
Its furthest displacement from the Equator is normally to about 45° S.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the MAPt?

options.text: The point in an instrument approach procedure which ensures that the minimum obstacle clearance is not infringed in case of a missed approach procedure.
The earliest point in an instrument approach at which a pilot must conduct a missed approach procedure.
The point at which the missed approach must be initiated if the required visual reference to continue the approach has not been established.
The point at which you can expect the ATC to issue a landing clearance.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the tropopause is correct?

options.text: The temperature lapse rate changes abruptly at the tropopause.
The temperature remains constant above and below the tropopause.
The temperature of the tropopause at the equator and at the poles is equal.
The temperature in the tropopause layer is isothermal, in the lower stratosphere the lapse rate becomes negative.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the tropopause is correct?

options.text: over the North Pole than over the equator.
over the equator than over the South Pole.
south of the equator than north of it.
in summer than winter in moderate latitudes.

A North American radar network for the detection of tornadoes.

options.text: ADFs can receive and take bearings from every broadcasting station provided it transmits within the frequency 190-1 750 kHz.
ADFs can receive every broadcasting station, provided it transmits within the frequency band 190-1 750 kHz, but cannot take bearings on them.

NDBs are amplitude modulated in contrast to broadcasting stations which are frequency modulated. ADFs can therefore not receive broadcasting stations, even if they transmit in the frequency band 190-1 750 kHz.
ADFs cannot receive broadcasting stations which transmit in the frequency band 190-1 750 kHz because NDBs are either NON/A1A or A2A modulated and broadcasting stations are A3A modulated.

It takes control of the flight controls when necessary to provide clearance between other traffic.

variant.question: What does the abbreviation "APV" mean?

options.text: Approach Procedure with Vertical guidance. It is an instrument procedure which utilises lateral and vertical guidance but does not meet the requirements established for precision approach and landing operations.
Approach Performed only in VMC. The restriction of an approved procedure to land at an aerodrome onyl when the aerodromes' ATS unit reports VMC.

Aerodrome Proximity Visualisation. It is an augmented-reality visualisation through any computer-based system of the essential elements at or in the close vicinity of an aerodrome, such as obstacle and signs.

Aerodrome Probable Visibility. The visibility used in case of failure of visibility-measuring instruments at an aerodrome, based on estimates by a human observer with knowledge of the aerodrome environment.
